titleStmt.title: Places Visited by Mary Richardson
titleStmt.funder: American Philosophical Society, Beinecke Library, Bibliographical Society of America, Blossman Foundation, Huntington Library, Louisiana Board of Regents, National Endowment for the Humanities, NINES, Pierpont Morgan Library, South Central Modern Language Association, and Southeastern Louisiana University

distributor.name: Southeastern Louisiana University Department of English

sourceDesc.p: Born digitally, prepared by David C. Hanson.

event.label: Mary departs Glenfarg for the next leg of her tour.

note.p: While in Glenfar, Mary enjoyed a pint of Guinness.

event.label: Passed through in route to Dover.

note.p: Mary states they walked up Blackheath and Shooter's Hill to get to Dartford.

terrain.desc: An area located in the Greenwich bourough of east London.

event.label: Passed through in route to Dover.

note.p: Walked up Shooter's Hill before arriving at Dartford.

event.label: Pass through in route to Dover.

note.p: Changed at Dartford before reaching Rochester while in route to Dover.

terrain.desc: Mary says that it is one long hill.

event.label: Pass through in route to Dover.
Pass through in route to Dover

note.p: Dined in Canterbury after leaving Rochester.

event.label: Pass through in route to Dover

note.p: Changed in Canterbury before reaching Dover.

event.label: Depart by steamboat at 9 for Calais.

note.p: Had tea after arrival, and breakfast at 8 before departure.

event.label: Arrived by English packet after two and a half hours at sea (English Channel).
Departed for Lille at 7 in the morning.

note.p: Mary says they were escorted to the Custom House, where their boxes and Anne were searched, by an officer. They stayed at L'hotel de Bourbon or Rossignol, toured the cathedral, and walked the town.
Stage 1 of this leg of the tour.
Stage 3.

terrain.desc: A town situated on a hill.

note.p: Meant only to dine, but was so pleased with the town that they decided to stay the night at Hotel d'Angelterre. They witnessed a procession of images of the Virgin Mary and Savior, followed by townsmen. The procession came from a church and went all round town. As the procession passed, the people in the town knelt and prayed.

event.label: Beginning of next leg of tour to Lille. Stage 1.

note.p: Stage 1.

event.label: Pass through in route to Lille

note.p: Stage 2.
Stage 3. Mary notes that they looked at a cathedral and visited a citadel. John Ruskin also drew.
Stage 1 of this leg of the tour.

terrain.desc: Before entering Tournai, French Custom House located at French/Belgian border.

note.p: Stage 2. Were stopped and searched at both French and Belgian Custom House.
Stage 1 of this leg of tour to Brussels.
Stage 2.
Stage 3.
Mary writes it as Hal. Stage 4.

terrain.desc: Hills can be seen from Rose Terrace.

note.p: While in Brussels, Mary says they stopped at Hotel de Ville bar in the Place Royale, where she first encountered a valet de chamber. Whent to an English church service performed by Mr. Drury, a companion of Lord Byron. She had taken walks with John James and John Ruskin in busy streets.

terrain.desc: Located within the city of Brussels.

note.p: Mary writes it as Laken. Unable to enter due to king and queen being in residence.

event.label: Arrived at 8:30 am to visit site of battle.

note.p: Visited to see Battle of Quatre Bras fallen soldiers monument at a church and battle site.
Stage 1 of trip to Spa.
Stage 2.

terrain.desc: Where the Sambre river meets the Meuse, which is a fine pebbly bed, and country well cultivated. The foritfications were well seen after crossing the bridge on the Huy road.

note.p: Stage 3. Mary is unimpressed.
Stage 1 of the day to Spa.
Stage 2. Admired a cathedral, visited a very old church build by the Spaniards and the Bishops palace.
Stage 3. Drank mineral water, and entered a church to hear music and mass.
Stage 1 of this leg of the journey.

Stayed at Hotel de Ville. Visit to a cathedral that has an octagonal roof with paintings and gallery for viewing. Houses pictures by Vandyke and Rubens, gobline tapestry, alter picture of Mary, which is a gift from Mary Queen of Scotts, and tomb of Charlemagne.
Written as Juilieres. Stage 1.
Stage 2. Not sure if they stayed at Reinbergh Hotel or Hotel Couronne Imperiale where George IV Stayed. Margaret stayed in bed while everyone else went to mass.
Mary took note of procession of girls and women, then men and boys.
Walked to church on hill and met Mr. Schlegal.

terrain.desc: Ruins - not very pretty. Between Bonn and Andernach.

note.p: Built in 1210.
Built by Roland, a nephew of Charlemagne who was in love with a lady in a neighbouring convent on an island, just under his castle, which is not an inn.
Mary and John drew the old Roman tower before leaving for Coblentz.

terrain.desc: Ruins on opposite side of river from road to Coblentz.
Moselle falls into Rhine at Coblentz.

event.label: Stayed at hotel Cheval Blanc. Visited Ehrenbreitstein fortress.

note.p: Mary claims to hear the most wonderful echoes, including one of a man who blew a horn.

terrain.desc: Located along and next to Hunsr√ºck mountians.

note.p: Stage 3.

terrain.desc: Villages located on both sides of the river.

note.p: Stage 4.

terrain.desc: Located where the Rhine meets the Main river.

note.p: Visited and dined at a hotel filled with Roman emperor's party

terrain.desc: Lies accross the Rhine from Mainz.

note.p: Known for mineral Springs

terrain.desc: West of Wiesbaden, with the Main running through its center.

note.p: Stay at Hotel de Russie, which was built by a gentleman of property. Margaret stayed in bed while everyone else attended a German protestant church.
Stage 1 of the day to Heidelberg.
Stage 2.
Stage 3.
Stage 4.
Stage 5.

terrain.desc: Mary says that it is a very fine town that lies so beautifully at the foot of a hill with the river Neckar flowing close to it. They admired a castle on June 5.

note.p: Stage 6.
Stage 1 of the day.
Stage 2.
Mary writes it as Carlsruhe. Stage 3. They admired botanical gardens, and she takes note that their churches are too much like a theater.
Stage 1 of day to Kehl.
Stage 2.
Stage 3. A town enjoying fete.
Stage 1 of this leg.
Stage 2.
Stage 3.
Visit to Strasbourg Cathedral, and Church of St. Thomas where a monument of Marechal Comte de Saxe is housed.
Mary writes it as Offenbourg. Stage 1 of this leg in route to Schaffhausen.
Stage 2.

terrain.desc: Swiss-like cottages. So hilly, that they needed six horses. Picturesque town. Could seen the snowy summits of the Alps. The Rhine winds around richly cultivated fields and vineyards.

event.label: Arrived at 11 to a town with locked gates.

note.p: Attended German Protestant churches on Sunday, June 9. Walked through town to a curious old citadel. Walked by clear bright green river.

terrain.desc: Ugly town but fine view of lake.

note.p: Breakfast until noon on June 11, then to Pfeffers.

event.label: Visit to the baths of Pfeffers.

note.p: Baths lie quite in a hole, and the house is the most miserable place ever seen.

terrain.desc: Wild and beautiful pass of the Alps.
Grand pass with immense high rocks that rise almost perpendicularly on each side of the Rhine. Houses surrounded by richly cultivated land are found on the lower parts of the mountains.

note.p: A poor place. Wet with no view.

terrain.desc: A small Italian town by high hills with very narrow streets, near a fine 300 foot high waterfall.

event.label: Off to see Fiume Latte, an Italian torrential river.

note.p: Visited Somariva to see paintings and statues. Impressed with terraces containing pomegranites, olives, lemons, and myrtle. Attended Italian mass on Sunday, June 16.
Looked at theatrical cathedral.

Saw magnificient cathedral with white marble, amphitheatre built by Napoleon, which can hold 42,000 spectators, and arch by Bonapart. They had ripe apricots and raspberries for dinner. Went to opera at Canobiano. On June 19, they went to Milan cathedral, Emperor's palace, Ambrosian Library, and Corso. On June 20, they went to Marengo Gate, San Lorenzo Basilica, and La Scala
Visited a rice field and Certosa, a monastary.
Stopped on June 21 due to a heavy storm.

terrain.desc: Lies in a bay. Streets are narrow and dirty.

note.p: Mary, Margaret and John Hames went to mass on June 23, St. John the Baptist's eve, without John Ruskin. There were bonfires and fireworks. On June 24, they attended military mass, visited several palaces and universities, Lord Byron's house, a cathedral that holds the remains of St. John the Baptist, and the Opera of Anna Boleyna. On June 25, they bought collars with rich work and ortolans for dinner.
Pleasant but hot town.
In route to Turin.

Makes note of elegant rooms in palace. Anne and Salvador accompany children on walk to see insects and lizards on Thursday, June 27. There was a violent storm on June 28. St. Peter's day was Saturday, June 29. They went to the Royal chapel to seen the king and queen. They took a ride in the country, then visited the Argens Theatre.Sunday, June 30 they walked to Villa regina, which was more Italian than anything they had seen.
Written as Navaro.

event.label: Off for quick trip to visit Angera and Varese

note.p: They liked Arona better than Como, although inferior. Visited 112 feet bronze statue of S. Carlo Borromeo.
Mary describes it as a busy town where silk is made.
Visit to palace of Borromean family.
Largest of the three Borromean Islands.
Mary writes it as Bavenna. Says it is at the end of the lake.
Duomo d'Ossala, as written by Mary, is a town in Ossola. She says that tt has splended views trhough passes equal to the Splugen.
Passed houses belonging to monks, and passed through galleries blown out of the rock. Brigg could be seen from far away.

terrain.desc: Marshy and not so pretty looking.

event.label: According to John James, they stayed in Sion on July 5.

note.p: Mary describes the town as dirty and desolate, with miserable creatures.
Unsure where they came from.

terrain.desc: Small town at the foot of Mont St. Bernard.

event.label: Return from walk to St. Pierre. Stay at St. Bernard hospice.

note.p: Stayed at the convent of St. Bernard, also know as St. Bernard Hospice. Mary notes that they woke to the sound of monks performing organ music at mass.

terrain.desc: Small town at the foot of Mont St. Bernard.

note.p: Bourg-Saint-Pierre is the village of St. Pierre

terrain.desc: Mary says that it is a vault or prison.
Located on a hill above Lake Geneva.

note.p: Mary says that someone bought Scott's Life of Swift and Rokeby. John James read the Swift life aloud in the evening. They visited Gibbon's and Kemble's houses on Sunday, July 14 after service.

terrain.desc: Strangest built town possible. One street is on the top of the houses of the street below. All streets are so steep that it is almost impossible for carriages to ascend.

note.p: Purchased needle work from a nun on June 16.
Went to Monastary of Capuchins and college of Jesuits.
Clean town. Women wear black velvet capes close to their heads. Stayed at Hotel de Couronne. Appreciate comfortable, but not well furnished rooms. Went to French protestant church on Sunday, July 21.

event.label: Return from Interlaken in route back to Berne.

note.p: Women row boats.
Visit to Giesbach Falls.
Visit to Lake of Sempach on July 23.
Visited garden of French officer who allows people to view Lake of Lucerne form his situation. Saw the Lion Monument.
Where other tourists gathered in hope of ascending Mount Righi. On July 25, they ascended Righi on horses. Celebrated Brother William's birthday on July 26.
Visit to Giesbach Falls.
A place of pilgrimage, to which the poor walk hundreds of miles in order to pay their devotions and to get things touched by the Virgin's shrine which acts as charms..
Attended mass on Sunday, July 28. On July 29, someone copied a picture of D's bridge on the route de Saint Gothard. John is ill.

You can see river flowing beneath you at hotel built out over a bridge. John is still ill, and they search for English books to amuse him. Walked to where Limmat and Sil unite on August 1. Mills on river.On August 2, visit to museam and library.
John James to bath. John Ruskin goes out first time since illness.
Stein am Rhein. Crossed river on kind of bridge boat, which pulled to opposite by chain on a whee.
Crossed Rhine in Rheinfel in order to enter Basel.
Entered during battle at Leickstall between peasants and townspeople. The town was shut because Basel men were killed by peasants.
Also spelled Solothurn. View of Roman tower and beautiful church.
Written as Iverdon.
Stay during festival, even though dificult to find lodgings.

terrain.desc: Cloth in Vegetation. Rhone River flows through town, split into two with houses built on island between.

note.p: Lots of English people in Geneva. Suspension bridge to hotel offers good view of Mont Blanc. English service on August 11, then evening walk with view of Mont Blanc. Visit Mr. Botte's showroom to buy jewelry. John sketched waterfall of Nant d'Arpenaz during return. They visited Marquis of Hertford's family with Lady Loveill on August 20, then the library, opera, and Voltaire's residence.

terrain.desc: Half way between Geneva and Chamouni.

note.p: Stopped for dinner during heavy storm.
Still raining on August 14.

terrain.desc: Richly cultivated land with beautiful road winding in a valley by side of Arve.

note.p: Rain continues. Visit Mer de Glace.
Also known as Mer de Glace. Lies in Chamouni. Witnessed small avalanche.
Visit museum on August 24 to see Le Brun resurrection, last supper by Philippe de Champagne, drawings by Poussin, and Sneyders wild boar hunt. Attended French protestant church on August 25.
